awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Role of Moisture Transport in Rainfall Variability and Agricultural Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the link between atmospheric processes and decisions made by farming households that depend on rainfall for food security.  By exploring linkages between rainfall variability and climate-related agricultural decisions, the project will expand basic understanding of how improved climate knowledge systems can lead to better agro-economic decisions by local subsistence farming communities.  Outcomes from this research will serve as a key resource for the community to deepen its understanding of what information sources of weather patterns assessments to rely upon.  Furthermore, by investigating the connectivity between atmospheric conditions and knowledge systems, the project will provide a critical step toward promoting food security and regional stability.  The project will advance STEM education in the US through K-12 educator development and online courses, as well as opportunities for students to participate virtually in field experiences.  The project also includes outreach to underrepresented populations in STEM at the university and K-12 levels.

Developing a better understanding of the climatic drivers of complex rainfall regimes including the sources of moisture will lead to more reliable scientific forecasting and improved decision-making by the agricultural communities.  Using Uganda as a case study, this project will (1) determine relationships between atmospheric and oceanic variables, seasonal rainfall totals, and wind direction over the past 30+ years; (2) evaluate the role of different moisture sources in daily to seasonal rainfall through isotopic and meteorological measurements; (3) identify and analyze the knowledge system used by farmers in order to determine how weather-related decisions are made; and (4) assess the agreement of farmers' observations and perceptions of moisture sources and associated rainfall with measured physical data.  Spatio-temporal relationships between seasonal rainfall totals and various atmospheric and sea-surface temperature (SST) analyses will be investigated along with atmospheric and SST conditions of extreme seasons.  A mixed-methods approach will be used to analyze precipitation data and detail local knowledge systems through community interviews, household surveys, and weather-event reporting.  The research has far-ranging global socio-economic implications for rural farming communities that are highly susceptible to variable rainfall amounts and chronic food insecurity.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the research is to determine the importance of Congo moisture for the western Uganda with respect to rainfall timing and totals, through the study of Congo-derived weather and local knowledge systems. The four major research objectives are as follows: (1) determine climatological relationships between atmospheric and oceanic variables, seasonal rainfall totals, and westerly winds over the past 30+ years; (2) evaluate the role of Congo moisture in daily to seasonal rainfall through geochemical and meteorological measurements; (3) identify and analyze the knowledge system (information, actors, transmission networks) used by farmers in order to determine how climate-related decisions are made; and (4) assess the congruence of farmers? observations and perceptions of Congo moisture and associated rainfall with measured physical data as well as how farmers? decisions are influenced by perceived changes in Congo moisture and rainfall. The two major objectives pertaining to broader impacts are as follows: (2) infuse research in student training to improve STEM education; and (2) build new collaborative relationships with scientists, managers, and policy makers to integrate research results into management plans, policy plans, and other activities at multiple geographic scales.

The results of the project had significant intellectual merit. The findings of lengthening rainy seasons, which led to wetter rainy seasons, should impact climate-science knowledge of equatorial Africa, since the prevailing view has been that of a drying trend for the region as a whole. We have shown that a biased satellite-based rainfall product, ARC2 (African Rainfall Climatology version 2), is responsible for the researchers concluding that a drying trend exists. It is hoped that other researchers focused on equatorial Africa will look more closely at their rainfall data and make sure that any drying trend they observe is not artificial (e.g., a drying trend caused by a reduction in rain gauges in a region). The two satellite-based products for use in western Uganda are CHIRPS (Climate Hazards Group InfraRed Precipitation with Station data) and TAMSAT (Tropical Applications of Meteorology using SATellite data and ground-based observation). Our research also has shown that Congo westerlies might contribute substantially to rainfall, especially during June-August and September-November, but were not responsible for the wetting trends. Our subsequent research casts some doubt on the importance of Congo westerlies: NCEP-NCAR Reanalysis 1, the reanalysis product used to simulate the westerlies, appears to be biased towards westerly flow. Substantial research on the teleconnections between rainfall and sea surface temperatures (SSTs) had been conducted across equatorial Africa as a whole, but there were no focused examinations for western Uganda. Our research on teleconnection between rainfall and SSTs shows that northwestern Uganda and southwestern Uganda have different teleconnections; therefore, those regions should be treated separately. For example, northwestern Uganda is much more affected by El Ni?o Southern Oscillation than is southwestern Uganda. We also show that two reanalyses JRA55 (Japan Meteorological Agency 55-year Reanalysis) and ERA5 (ECMWF Reanalysis v5) are the best products for analyzing lower-troposphere winds in western Uganda. Our analyses of isotopes revealed distinct differences in the δ18O, δ17O, δ2H, d-excess and ∆17O in precipitation sourced from easterly vs. westerly locations. In addition, rainfall that occurs during the dry seasons, which is disruptive to rain-fed agriculture, may be associated with pulses of evapotranspired (recycled) vapor. Finally, through the use of household surveys and satellite-based rainfall estimates, we show that an alignment of farmer recall with recent rainfall patterns predicts higher yields in the present year, thereby suggesting that farmers may translate their cumulative record of environmental knowledge into productive on-farm decisions.

The project had significant broader impacts. The largest impact was that on the intellectual and professional STEM development of students in the United States and Uganda. An undergraduate student in the United States acquired software-analysis skills and completed some initial analyses of the data. A graduate student was involved in the climatology-related research activities and completed an M.S. thesis. Personnel based in Uganda were trained to use rainwater collectors and record metadata pertaining to the rainwater collection. Other Ugandan personnel have been trained to administer surveys to farmers. There also was a community-science component: farmers were trained to observe and record daily atmospheric variables. Finally, the research was presented multiple times to staff members of the Uganda National Meteorological Authority, which is the organization responsible for seasonal rainfall forecasts.
